oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Teaching Pharmacology and Toxicology as Basic Sciences in the Veterinary Medical Curriculum
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Short, Charles R.
Aronson, Carl E.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: veterinary education
pharmacology
toxicology
laboratory sessions
teaching
curriculum
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The current status of veterinary pharmacology and toxicology, as taught in U.S. and Canadian schools, is examined from the stand-point of curricular content and placement, the value of laboratory sessions, and the influence of external factors which may affect the teaching of these subjects over the next decade. The results of two independent surveys show that an average of 97.8 hr of basic pharmacology, 18.3 hr of clinical pharmacology and 40.9 hr of toxicology are presented, with wide variations in total contact between institutions. Twenty-three schools present laboratory sessions in pharmacology, while only four do so in toxicology. The vast majority of respondents found substantial value in laboratory sessions as a teachng mode, and nearly every school presenting laboratories conducts animal experiments. Video tape is widely used for demonstration purposes, but computer-aided instruction, as an alternative to animal laboratories, is not yet popular. Financial restrictions, pressure from animal rights groups, and restrictive legislation are all seen as factorsÂ· which will pressure animal laboratories in the future. It is concluded that while the format may change, laboratories will continue to be an important mode of instruction in pharmacology.
